text: This paper explores the question Can recent advances in AI and HCI power intelligent, interactive, and accessible reading interfaceseven for legacy PDFs?
label: novelty

text: We describe the Semantic Reader Project, a collaborative effort across multiple institutions to explore automatic creation of dynamic reading interfaces for research papers.
label: novelty

text: Through this project, we've developed ten research prototype interfaces and conducted usability studies with 300+ participants and real-world users showing improved reading experiences for scholars.
label: result

text: We've also released a production research paper reader that will incorporate novel features as they mature.
label: novelty

text: We structure this paper around challenges scholars and the public face when reading research papersdiscovery, efficiency, comprehension, synthesis, and accessibilityand present an overview of our progress and remaining open challenges.
label: method

text: This raises an exciting challenge: Can we create intelligent, interactive, and accessible reading interfaces for research papers, even atop existing PDFs?
label: method

text: To explore this question, we present the Semantic Reader Project , a broad collaborative effort across multiple non-profit, industry, and academic institutions to create interactive, intelligent reading interfaces for research papers.
label: novelty

text: This project consists of three pillars: research, product, and open science resources.
label: method

text: We developed research prototypes and conducted usability studies that clarify their benefits.
label: novelty

text: On the product front, we are developing the Semantic Reader (Figure 1), 1 a freely available reading interface that integrates features from research prototypes as they mature.
label: novelty

text: 2 Finally, we are developing and releasing open science resources that drive both the research and the product.
label: novelty

text: In this paper, we focus on summarizing our efforts under the research pillar of the Semantic Reader Project.
label: novelty

text: We structure our discussion around five broad challenges faced by readers of research papers:  Discovery: Following paper citations is one of the main strategies that scholars employ to discover additional relevant papers, but keeping track of the large numbers of citations can be overwhelming.
label: method

text: In 2, we explore ways to visually augment research papers to help readers prioritize their paper exploration during literature reviews.
label: novelty

text: In 3, we explore how support for non-linear reading can help readers consume research papers more efficiently.
label: novelty

text: In 4, we explore how providing in-situ definitions and summaries can benefit readers especially when reading outside of their domains.
label: novelty

text: In 5, we explore how to help readers collect information from and make sense of many papers to gain better understanding of broad research topics.
label: novelty

text: In 6, we explore methods for converting legacy papers to more accessible representations.
label: novelty

text: We conclude by discussing ongoing research opportunities in both AI and HCI for developing the future of scholarly reading interfaces.
label: novelty

text: We provide pointers to our production reading interface and associated open resources to invite the broader research community to join our effort.
label: method

text: Here we discuss how interactive reading interfaces can help scholars more effectively explore citations to important relevant work in both directions with two systems called CiteSee [15] and CiteRead [82].
label: method

text: To address this, CiteSee provides a personalized research paper reading experience by automatically identifying and resolving inline citations in PDFs to research paper entities in our academic graph [50], and visually augmenting inline citations based on their connections to the current reader.
label: method

text: In this section we discuss two systems, Scim [28] and Ocean [75], which demonstrate different approaches to helping readers navigate efficiently through a paper toward high-value, relevant information.
section: 2 UNLOCKING CITATIONS FOR DISCOVERY @@ 2.2 Exploring Future Work with CiteRead
label: result

text: In this section, we discuss several ways in which interactive reading aids can help a reader understand a paper with less work through three systems: ScholarPhi [33], PaperPlain [1] and Papeo [92].
label: method

text: How can we design interactive aids that present definitions of terms when and where readers most need them?
label: method

text: Can we make complex texts more approachable by incorporating plain language summaries in the margins of the text?
section: @@ 4.2 Simplifying Complex Passages with Paper Plain
label: method

text: To grant authors more control over how their work is presented, we developed an AI-supported authoring interface for linking paper passages and videos efficiently: candidate passages are linked to excerpts of videos as suggestions using a pretrained language model [100], and an author interactively confirms or refines them.
section: @@ 4.2 Simplifying Complex Passages with Paper Plain
label: method

text: Our early-stage evaluations of Papeo suggest that readers can use these interactions to fluidly transition between watching video and reading text, using video to quickly understand, and then selectively descending into the text when they desire a detailed understanding of the paper.
section: @@ 4.2 Simplifying Complex Passages with Paper Plain
label: method

text: One question is how to integrate the different kinds of functionality across these projects into one coherent user interface, especially as we migrate research features into the production interface.
label: method

text: Finally is the question of how we can allow the scholarly community to step in where current AI systems fall short, such as by fixing improperly-extracted content or incorrect generated text which are especially problematic for interfaces such as SciA11y (6).
label: method

text: The bar for deploying AI models to support real-world reading is high; we often found during iterative design and usability studies that even slight errors in these models can have detrimental effects on the readers.
label: result

text: For example, when developing Paper Plain (4.2), LLMs enabled us to quickly test different granularities and complexity-levels of plain language summaries with participants, eschewing the need for expensive changes to data requirements and model retraining.
label: method

text: In the near-term, we will revisit interface designs relying on bespoke AI models to evaluate whether LLMs can close the gap between research prototype and ready-for-production (e.g., more accurate definition identification for ScholarPhi 4.1).
label: method

text: While recent work has shown that these models can occasionally make critical errors or generate factually incorrect text when processing scientific text [72], we remain cautiously optimistic about developing ways to address their limitations [25, 55].
label: result

text: Finally, all the new interfaces for reading that we propose pose a number of important ethical considerations that will require further research and discussion.
label: method

text: Another tension that we have encountered is the potential discrepancy between author desires and reader desires for how a work is presented and how much control to provide authors.
label: method

text: For instance, in our work on Papeo (4.3), we found that authors desired control over placement of their talk video snippets, even as they found automated mapping support to be helpful.
label: result

text: Instead of simply seeking to increase reading throughput uniformly, our systems should enable triage , so that readers can dedicate time for thoughtful and careful reading when the content is important.
label: method

text: For instance, our systems could design pathways that, while they may be more efficient, do not obfuscate the full context (e.g., Scim 3.1), and that encourage good practices such as verification and provenance tracing.
label: method

text: This paper describes the Semantic Reader Project, which currently consists of ten research prototypes focusing on supporting scientists around Discovery [15, 82], Efficiency [28, 75], Comprehension [1, 33, 92], Synthesis [43, 73], and Accessibility [91, 97] when reading research papers.
label: method

text: Validating our approach of augmenting existing PDFs of research papers, we have seen tremendous adoption of the freely-available Semantic Reader product 1 which has grown to 10k weekly users.
label: novelty

text: 7 While we focused on augmenting PDF documents to support common scholar reading practices, all of our reading interfaces are built with web technologiesallowing these novel interactions to extend to future publication formats which can be rendered in web browsers.
label: novelty

text: We plan to continue experimenting with novel AI-powered intelligent reading interfaces, as well as migrating successful interactive features into the product.
label: novelty

text: Finally, we offer a collection of freely-available resources to the larger research community, including datasets of open-access research papers [61], APIs for accessing the academic citation graph [50], machine learning models for processing and understanding research papers [11, 20, 42, 86], 4 and open-source software for rendering and augmenting PDF documents for developing reading interfaces.
label: novelty

text: 3 We hope by providing these resources we can enable and encourage the broader research community to work on exciting novel intelligent reading interfaces for research papers with us.
label: novelty

text: This project is supported in part by NSF Grant OIA-2033558, NSF Grant CNS-2213656.
label: method
